‚Äú‚Äã‚ÄãEl oc√©ano est√° sometido a numerosos factores estresantes, derivados de un uso abusivo por parte de los seres humanos, y de ser instaladas indiscriminadamente y sin los adecuados cuidados, las plantas desaladoras podr√≠an sumar a deteriorar a√∫n m√°s la salud de los ecosistemas marinos, de los organismos que viven en ellos y de los procesos oce√°nicos que permiten la vida en la Tierra‚Äù, recalc√≥ la bi√≥loga de la Fundaci√≥n.

No solo el medio ambiente: La pesca artesanal tambi√©n corre peligro

‚ÄúUn ejemplo emblem√°tico es lo que ocurre en Mejillones donde, hoy en d√≠a, el mar tiene un color caracter√≠stico de tono turquesa. Ello ocurre porque no hay surgencia: el agua es cristalina, sin vida y eso es lo que nos preocupa a nosotros sobre lo que pueda pasar con la pesca artesanal. Se perdieron las especies y, es b√°sicamente la devoluci√≥n de la salmuera, lo que hace estos ecosistemas est√©riles‚Äù, explica la directora de la ONG, citada por LaReddelSur.

‚ÄúHay que pensar que la vida marina se encuentra principalmente dentro de las primeras diez millas, es ah√≠ donde se reclutan los peces y donde viven su vida juvenil, por lo que si alteras ese espacio, despu√©s no vas a tener pesquer√≠as sustentables en alta mar. Hay que entender que esto es un ecosistema en que la afectaci√≥n va a ser en su totalidad y no solamente en el punto donde se produzca la descarga de salmuera‚Äù, a√±adi√≥.

Ante esta situaci√≥n, se est√° trabajando en un proyecto para que las decisiones que se tomen con respecto a las plantas desalinizadoras sean aprobadas tras investigaciones cient√≠ficas.

‚ÄúLa propuesta, es que hay que incluir a la ciencia para que la actividad sea sostenible socio ecol√≥gicamente: desde el punto de vista del consumo humano, la actividad productiva y la ecolog√≠a. La idea, es justamente guiar un poco la toma de decisiones, la pol√≠tica p√∫blica, bas√°ndonos en evidencias cient√≠ficas, para ver d√≥nde es m√°s id√≥neo o no este tipo de plantas‚Äù, puntualiz√≥ el investigador del Centro de Estudios Avanzados de Zonas √Åridas (CEAZA) de la Regi√≥n de Coquimbo, V√≠ctor Aguilera.

Para Aguilera, es importante que todas las actividades que del ser humano y que tengan interacci√≥n con el medio ambiente, deben ser evaluadas, para que este no se vea afectado.

title: Acci√≥n temprana: La urgencia de reorientar el apoyo estatal hacia la protecci√≥n del oc√©ano | Ladera Sur
text:
En el D√≠a Metereol√≥gico Mundial, Diego Lillo Goffreri, nuestro colaborador invitado, quien es abogado del programa de Ecosistemas de la Asociaci√≥n Interamericana para la Defensa del Ambiente (AIDA), expone la importancia del oc√©ano y su labor vital en la crisis clim√°tica actual con una reflexi√≥n respecto al rol que han tenido las decisiones gubernamentales con la salmonicultura chilena, su impacto en el ecosistema marino y las medidas que deber√≠an ser tomadas para protegerlo.

Este 23 de marzo, el gobierno del presidente Gabriel Boric recibe su primer D√≠a Meteorol√≥gico Mundial, que a√±o a a√±o conmemora la creaci√≥n de la Organizaci√≥n Meteorol√≥gica Mundial (OMM) planteando una reflexi√≥n sobre la crisis clim√°tica global. Lo hace en buen momento, tras la esperada firma del Acuerdo de Escaz√∫ y con la intenci√≥n declarada de abordar la crisis clim√°tica con mayor transversalidad en los distintos sectores p√∫blicos, como fue anunciado en su discurso inaugural.

El tema planteado por la OMM para este a√±o es ‚ÄúAlerta temprana y Acci√≥n temprana‚Äù, que aparece como una discusi√≥n necesaria, sobre todo ante los alarmantes hallazgos publicados por el Panel Intergubernamental de Expertos sobre el Cambio Clim√°tico (IPCC por sus siglas en ingl√©s) en su informe m√°s reciente (1).

El √©nfasis que ese informe pone en la adaptaci√≥n permite comentar sobre las oportunidades del nuevo gobierno para implementar la acci√≥n temprana a trav√©s de medidas de adaptaci√≥n basadas en ecosistemas en un sector de particular importancia: el oc√©ano.

El oc√©ano es el principal regulador clim√°tico del planeta. Se calcula que ha absorbido entre el 20 y 30% de las emisiones antropog√©nicas de carbono y el 90% del exceso de calor en la atm√≥sfera (2). Esta funci√≥n crucial est√° bajo amenaza por el propio cambio clim√°tico ‚Äîdebido a la creciente acidificaci√≥n‚Äî y por otros impactos, entre ellos los de la contaminaci√≥n directa del oc√©ano, la industria extractiva de la pesca, la acuicultura y la miner√≠a submarina, por mencionar algunas.

Aleta Ballena Azul ¬©Marcelo Flores ‚Äì WWF Chile

Chile ha sido consciente de la importancia del oc√©ano. De hecho, en 2021, lleg√≥ a proteger un 88,76% de √°reas marinas, sobre los 18 millones de hect√°reas totales del sistema nacional de √°reas protegidas del Estado. Sin embargo, el escaso financiamiento disponible para esas √°reas es una primera alerta roja: el presupuesto para √°reas marinas en 2021 fue de $432.200.000, el 2.39% del total del presupuesto para √°reas protegidas y equivalente m√°s o menos a $3 pesos por hect√°rea.

En paralelo, el Estado ha impulsado una serie de programas de transferencias p√∫blicas para beneficio de la salmonicultura, una de las actividades que m√°s impacto ha causado en el mar en las √∫ltimas d√©cadas. Desde la Corporaci√≥n de Fomento de la Producci√≥n (CORFO), destacan el Consorcio Tecnol√≥gico para la Acuicultura Oce√°nica y el Programa Estrat√©gico Mesoregional Salm√≥n m√°s Sustentable, que han destinado m√°s de $4.500.000.000 para el mejoramiento del rendimiento econ√≥mico del salm√≥n sin considerar oportunidades de mejora de su desempe√±o ambiental.

El caso m√°s alarmante es el de la Ley Navarino, que se plante√≥ fomentar el poblamiento y desarrollo productivo de algunas zonas aisladas de la Regi√≥n de Magallanes. La √∫nica empresa salmonera que opera dentro del √°rea beneficiada es Nova Austral, que ha recibido m√°s de la mitad del total de los subsidios otorgados durante la vigencia de la Ley y que solo durante 2021 recibi√≥ $9.356.868.649.

La gravedad de este caso no termina ah√≠. Los centros salmoneros que se benefician con este subsidio se ubican en el interior del Parque Nacional Alberto de Agostini y han afectado gravemente sus ecosistemas (3). De hecho, la compa√±√≠a actualmente enfrenta un juicio penal precisamente por fraude a la normativa ambiental para la obtenci√≥n de los subsidios de Ley Navarino (4).

Salmoneras ‚Äì Gentileza Fundaci√≥n Terram (3)

La acci√≥n temprana que recomienda el IPCC, en el caso del oc√©ano chileno, requiere, como m√≠nimo, partir de un an√°lisis de la efectividad de los mecanismos de protecci√≥n actualmente vigentes. El gasto exiguo destinado a proteger las √°reas marinas no parece ser una inversi√≥n p√∫blica eficiente, mientras se financia fuertemente la expansi√≥n de una industria que tiene el efecto exactamente contrario. En rigor, e incluso considerando las multas cursadas al sector por infracciones ambientales (5), las cifras demuestran que el Estado de Chile ha favorecido m√°s la producci√≥n de impactos ambientales en el mar (muchas veces irreparables), que la gesti√≥n de las √°reas protegidas marinas.

La tendencia internacional en materia de subsidios es hacia la prohibici√≥n de aquellos que tienen un efecto negativo sobre los recursos naturales y su recuperaci√≥n.

Una pol√≠tica p√∫blica interna coherente con dicha tendencia y con la imperiosa necesidad de implementar medidas de adaptaci√≥n basadas en ecosistemas debiera apuntar hacia la instauraci√≥n de incentivos que promuevan la conservaci√≥n y recuperaci√≥n de los recursos pesqueros y acu√≠colas, as√≠ como al mejoramiento del nivel econ√≥mico de las comunidades costeras.

En ese contexto, se√±al√≥ que la triple crisis -cambio clim√°tico, p√©rdida de biodiversidad y contaminaci√≥n- afecta directamente al oc√©ano, de manera visible y cada vez m√°s severa. ‚ÄúLa CPPS ha recogido este desaf√≠o, al crear planes de trabajo en m√∫ltiples √°reas, incluyendo el Plan de Acci√≥n para la Protecci√≥n del Medio Marino del Pac√≠fico Sudeste‚Äù, afirm√≥.

Adem√°s, record√≥ que hace pocos d√≠as, en Punta Arenas, se lanz√≥ la pol√≠tica exterior turquesa, ‚Äúque consiste en una aproximaci√≥n transversal a los temas ambientales, a trav√©s de la integraci√≥n del azul del oc√©ano con el verde de los ecosistemas terrestres, y que incorpora una mirada de promoci√≥n y respeto de los derechos humanos‚Äù.

En la misma l√≠nea, destac√≥ que el Gobierno del Presidente Gabriel Boric ha buscado dar continuidad al inter√©s hist√≥rico de nuestro pa√≠s por el oc√©ano, a trav√©s del lanzamiento de la Coalici√≥n Am√©ricas por la Protecci√≥n del Oc√©ano, en la Cumbre de las Am√©ricas; proponiendo la aplicaci√≥n inmediata del principio precautorio por el posible inicio de la miner√≠a submarina; y trabajando en el marco de la Organizaci√≥n de Ordenamiento Pesquero del Pacifico Sur, para proteger los espacios que se encuentran en alta mar de las dorsales submarinas de Nazca y de Salas y G√≥mez.

Finalmente, los invit√≥ ‚Äúa sumarse a Chile en este esfuerzo, en donde los cuatro pa√≠ses costeros del Pacifico Sur podemos promover conjuntamente la protecci√≥n de ese espacio en el cual nos proyectamos, siendo vanguardistas nuevamente, tal como lo hicieron nuestros antecesores cuando dieron vida a la Declaraci√≥n que hoy celebramos‚Äù.

En el encuentro participaron el Ministro de Relaciones Exteriores del Per√∫, Miguel √Ångel Rodr√≠guez; los Viceministros de Colombia y Ecuador Francisco Jos√© Coy y Luis Vayas, adem√°s de la Viceministra de Relaciones Exteriores de Panam√°, Ana Luisa Castro, por ser pa√≠s observador y el Secretario General de la CPPS, Jos√© Luis P√©rez.

title: In the Yellow Sea, a shining example of marine protection
text:
It has been more than 20 years since South Korea and China began a novel partnership to restore and protect the shallow body of salt water that lies between them: the Yellow Sea, a semi-enclosed marine area bracketed by the Chinese mainland and the Korean peninsula.

The Yellow Sea‚Äôs amber-tinged waters and coastlines teem with 1,600 different species of fauna ‚Äì from dugongs and sea turtles to flounders and rockfish. The land around the sea also teems with humanity. More than 600 million people, or 10 percent of the global population, live on or near its shores and rely on its health for food and income.

A generation ago, it became increasingly clear that the rapid economic development of the surrounding region was placing a heavy strain on this fragile and valuable environment.

Over-fishing and pollution from industry, agriculture, and housing had depleted fish stocks, while many of the region‚Äôs tidal mudflats, key feeding grounds for migratory birds, had been lost to coastal reclamation. Biodiversity was also threatened by invasive species and ecosystem changes such as algal blooms and nutrient contamination.

To counterbalance these threats, the governments of China and the Republic of Korea began working with the Global Environment Facility and UN Development Programme (UNDP) in the mid-1990s to lay plans for the Yellow Sea Large Marine Ecosystem Project (YSLME).

A new report published by the YSLME project and available through the GEF‚Äôs International Waters knowledge-sharing platform IW:Learn details the array of innovative solutions introduced since the start of the Yellow Sea Large Marine Ecosystem project.

These have included the ranching of key marine species for reintroduction, government-led schemes to buy back fishing vessels and lessen pressure on stocks, enhanced monitoring of pollutants, and curbs on coastal reclamation and commercial fishing.

Harvesting kelp in Dongchu Village. Photo credit: Yitao Zhang

These initiatives have benefited the region in many ways: restoring marine forests around the picturesque island of Jeju to stem the spread of barren ground near the coast, helping to protect the tiny and critically endangered spoon-billed sandpiper, and encouraging cooperation with other countries to preserve the habitat of the spotted seal, one of the region‚Äôs flagship species.

The first phase of the project initially focused on helping the countries conduct a Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) of the Yellow Sea to pinpoint the most pressing environmental perils and their immediate and root causes.

This analysis formed the technical basis for the bilateral talks between China and the Republic of Korea that led up to the preparation and ministerial adoption of an initial Strategic Action Programme. Approved by both countries in 2009, the Programme set out pledges from the partners to take steps to reduce environmental pressures, such as fishing limits, improved management of sea and coastal areas, and pollution reduction targets.

A second phase of the project began in 2014 and closed in 2021. This phase resulted in the preparation of a new YSLME Strategic Action Programme for 2020-2030 and an updated TDA to guide and inform efforts.

A critical part of the initiative was the sharing of successes, challenges, and lessons, so other regions could learn from the marine restoration efforts of China and the Republic of Korea.

‚ÄúThanks to the results, experience and lessons from the Yellow Sea Large Marine Ecosystem Project, countries around the world are better equipped to put in place good practices on sustainable fisheries and aquaculture that can protect the ocean‚Äôs health and propel sustainable blue development,‚Äù said GEF CEO and Chairperson Carlos Manuel Rodriguez. ‚ÄúIt is a shining example of what can be achieved through cooperation on shared marine resources.‚Äù

title: Marine protection pays off in Zhejiang
text:
Yang Tiansheng, a fisherman from Xiangshan county, Zhejiang province, displays large yellow croakers he caught on Jan 15, 2022. [Photo provided to China Daily]

For fisherman Yang Tiansheng in Xiangshan county, Zhejiang province, the deep sea will always be filled with treasure, as long as it is well-protected and aquatic products are harvested in a scientific manner.

He told with excitement on Saturday about finding such a treasure.

"We hauled over 2,450 kilograms of large yellow croakers in a net on Friday," Yang said. "And the heaviest one weighed more than 2 kilograms."

Lin Haiping, the owner of the fishing boat on which Yang works, was immediately swarmed by buyers when he brought back the fish, the sales of which totaled 9.57 million yuan ($1.5 million).

"I've been fishing for 28 years but never caught so many yellow croakers of this size before," said Lin.

Fang Yue, chief engineer at the Xiangshan Water Resources and Fisheries Bureau, said, "It is the first time that fishermen have caught so many wild yellow croakers in the East China Sea in over three decades."

The yellow croaker, native to the western Pacific Ocean, is generally found in temperate waters such as the East China Sea and the Yellow Sea, and has long served as a local specialty in coastal Ningbo, Zhejiang.

Most yellow croakers available in markets have been farm-raised and sell for between 30 and 60 yuan per kg, while those harvested from the ocean can be quite expensive, with larger ones selling for as much as 8,000 yuan per kg.

Large wild yellow croakers used to be abundant in the East China Sea, but the number has been dropping since about 45 years ago due to overfishing.

In 1979, Zhejiang launched an annual seasonal moratorium on fishing. It has been updated and promoted nationally since 1995, as part of efforts to promote sustainable fishing and improve the marine environment.

Fang said that the resurgence in the number of wild yellow croakers has resulted from the marine protection efforts.

According to the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, the moratorium, which begins every summer and lasts more than three months, covers the Bohai Sea, the Yellow Sea, the East China Sea and waters north of 12 degrees north latitude in the South China Sea.

During this period, safety inspections of fishing gear and a cleanup of illegal fishing vessels are carried out in these areas.

"The local authorities have released more than 10 species of fish in the East China Sea over the past five years. According to the monitoring data, the number of fish larvae is rising every year," said Fang.

He also emphasized the great contribution that fishermen from Xiangshan have made.

In 2000, 21 fishermen in Xiangshan founded China's first volunteer organization to better protect the seas and oceans around the world.

To date, more than 10,000 people have joined the organization.

In 2002, three fishermen from the county wrote to Kofi Annan, then secretary-general of the United Nations, calling on people around the world to protect the seas together.

Huang Genbao, head of the Xiangshan Fishing Association, said that although harvesting more than 1,000 kg of large yellow croakers doesn't happen often, he hoped that marine resource protection efforts will continue and more fishermen will have big hauls in the future.

Yu Yin in Ningbo contributed to this story.

title: Tiny nation puts 'Great' Britain to shame with heroic ocean protection plan
text:
The small island nation of Niue aims to protect 100% of the ocean it has jurisdiction over, according to the Guardian. Its plan to do so contrasts sharply with the UK‚Äôs ocean-focused efforts. As the same publication recently pointed out, the UK is failing to safeguard even its already designated ‚Äòprotected‚Äô areas.

In short, Britain is not so ‚Äògreat‚Äô when it comes to ocean protection. It‚Äôs lagging far behind teeny nations like Niue, despite having far more resources at its disposal.

Leading by example

Coastal nations have territorial rights over a certain amount of the ocean surrounding them, beyond their territorial waters. This is known as an Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). The Guardian reported on 30 May that Niue has introduced a plan to protect 100% of its EEZ.

The plan, which has been in force since April, involves the creation of a ‚Äúmultiple-use‚Äù marine park. The country has zoned different parts of the park for specific purposes. It‚Äôs banned fishing in some zones, allowed small-scale fishing and recreation activities in others, and has a set area for commercial fishing. There‚Äôs also a ‚Äúconservation zone‚Äù that boats can pass through but not dally in.

As Mongabay highlighted, the Cook Islands passed an Act in 2017 that laid out a similar 100% protection plan for its waters.

Setting a bad example

Compare Niue‚Äôs efforts with the UK. According to the Joint Nature Conservation Committee, an advisory body, the country has designated 36% of its offshore waters as Marine Protected Areas (MPAs). But analysis shared with the Guardian suggests that these are little more than ‚Äòpaper parks‚Äô, meaning protected in name but not in practice.

Global Fishing Watch and Oceana provided the analysis to the Guardian. They found that bottom trawling and dredging is taking place in over 90% of the UK‚Äôs offshore MPAs. Bottom trawling is a highly destructive form of fishing favoured by big commercial vessels ‚Äì supertrawlers ‚Äì that involves dragging weighed nets across the seabed.

Read on...

The data showed that in 2021, ‚Äúfishing with bottom-towed gear‚Äù took place in no less than 58 of the 64 offshore MPAs designated as ‚Äúbenthic‚Äù. As the Guardian explained, these MPAs are specifically meant to ‚Äúprotect species that live on the seabed‚Äù.

Responding to the findings, a Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) spokesperson listed the fishing-related changes since Brexit. These include an upcoming ban on trawling in four MPAs; possible management changes in 13 other MPAs; a seafood fund to promote ‚Äúinnovation and sustainability‚Äù; consultation on a joint fisheries statement; and the ‚Äúlandmark Fisheries Act 2020‚Äù.

There‚Äôs the way but not the will

Of the upcoming trawling ban, Greenpeace‚Äôs Will McCallum said:

It‚Äôs taken two years [since Brexit] for the government to introduce trawling bans on four MPAs. The whole thing is taking too long and at the end, you have a ban on a single gear type ‚Äì bottom-towed gear. But, in theory, a supertrawler could go straight though it.

Greenpeace has regularly fought against the government‚Äôs permissive attitude towards destructive fishing. In 2020 and 2021, for example, it dropped boulders into some MPAs to literally stop bottom trawlers in their tracks. The government‚Äôs Marine Management Organisation (MMO) responded by taking Greenpeace to court, a case it has since dropped.

That reaction is unsurprising in light of the Conservatives‚Äô resistance to strengthening fishing laws. In 2020, Conservative MPs successfully defeated proposed amendments to the Fisheries Bill, the precursor to the aforementioned ‚Äòlandmark‚Äô Act. These amendments were to keep fishing quotas within sustainable limits based on scientific advice and to ban supertrawlers in MPAs.

In short, the government appears to lack the will to take meaningful action to protect the ocean, despite being well equipped to do so. As Greenpeace has highlighted, the MMO issues licences to bottom trawlers and has the power to:

exclude specific fishing methods from specific areas, or even exclude boats entirely.

The right idea

Niue has the opposite problem. It appears to have the will to comprehensively protect the surrounding ocean, but lacks the means to do so entirely independently. It is a small island nation that is self-governing and, like the Cook Islands, maintains ‚Äòfree association‚Äò with New Zealand. As such, it‚Äôs reliant on neighbours, like other islands and New Zealand, to help police its waters. Global Fishing Watch also assists with monitoring of the marine park through satellite surveillance.

Niue and other island nations clearly aren‚Äôt short of the right ideas though. Over-fishing is one of the top threats to the ocean, of which there are many. Stringently protecting the ocean from it is essential.

title: Bold ocean protection plan could help right one of the UK's historic wrongs
text:
This story was produced as part of the 2022 UN Ocean Conference Fellowship organized by Internews‚Äô Earth Journalism Network with support from the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation (UK Branch).

Britain‚Äôs expulsion of Chagos islanders from their Indian Ocean home in the 1960s and 70s is a shameful moment in its history. The eviction, which the UK carried out after allegedly pressuring Mauritius to sell it the islands ahead of independence, is an enduring part of the former‚Äôs colonial legacy. Chagossians continue to fight for the right to return home to this day.

At the recent UN Ocean Conference in Portugal, Mauritius laid out an ambitious plan. It could enable the resettlement of some Chagossians on the islands. The proposal involves the establishment of a vast Marine Protected Area (MPA) in the Chagos archipelago.

‚ÄòGet some rocks which will remain ours‚Äô

As historian and journalist Mark Curtis explained in his book Web of Deceit: Britain‚Äôs Real Role in the World, the UK effectively created a new colony during its mid-20th Century decolonisation process. Curtis noted that a UK official laid out their aim in a secret file, namely to ‚Äúget some rocks which will remain ours‚Äù. The new colony included Mauritius‚Äôs Chagos archipelago and islands which were part of the Seychelles. The UK named this area the British Indian Ocean Territory (BIOT).

Since 1966, the UK has leased some of these ‚Äòrocks‚Äô to the US military. It brutally removed the Chagossians to facilitate the deal and assert its claim to the islands, allegedly poisoning and gassing the islanders‚Äô beloved dogs in the process. The US has a base on Diego Garcia, the archipelago‚Äôs biggest island, which was given its name by the UK, according to the organisation CAGE.

The UK handed the Seychelles its islands back in 1976 when it gained independence, ostensibly because the US and UK militaries didn‚Äôt plan to use them. But it has fought tooth and claw to keep hold of the Chagos archipelago. The US military lease there doesn‚Äôt expire until 2036.

Illegal MPA

The UK created a massive Marine Protected Area/ MPA around the archipelago in 2010. It claims the MPA serves to ‚Äúensure the future protection‚Äù of the highly biodiverse waters. But WikiLeaks has released US state department cables that indicate UK officials believed the MPA would stymie resettlement of Chagossians for the long-term.

Read on...

Mauritius challenged the legality of the MPA under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). As David Snoxell, the UK‚Äôs Chagos Islands All-Party Parliamentary Group (APPG) coordinator, recently wrote in Mauritian publication l‚ÄôExpress Weekly, the BIOT MPA banned Mauritius from inshore fishing in Chagos waters. The UK had committed to such access for Mauritius in the original agreement for the purchase of the islands.

The UNCLOS tribunal ruled the MPA unlawful in a 2015 decision.

Successive rulings against the UK

This is just one in a series of determinations against the UK in relation to the archipelago in recent years.

The International Court of Justice (ICJ) issued an advisory ruling in 2019 that the separation of the islands was unlawful. Later that year, a majority of UN member states also voted in a non-binding resolution that the UK should hand the territory back to Mauritius.

In 2021, the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS) confirmed Mauritius‚Äôs sovereignty over the Chagos Islands and urged the UK to end its occupation of them. ITLOS is currently engaged in establishing the maritime boundaries between Mauritius and the Maldives, known as delimiting. Once that‚Äôs done, the former intends to move forward with its own plan for an extensive MPA.

Biodiversity, sovereignty, and resettlement

Mauritius laid out the plan at an event at the UN Ocean Conference on 1 July. Dr Rezah Badal, director general of the Department for Continental Shelf, Maritime Zones Administration & Exploration, ‚Äãexplained that the country will take a ‚Äúscientific approach‚Äù to the MPA.

It will rely on four key principles, he said. These are:

Biodiversity preservation and protection.

‚ÄúRestitution of the cultural assets‚Äù of the archipelago.

Resettlement of Mauritians, including Chagossians, along with ‚Äúaccompanying sustainable fisheries‚Äù.

Maritime security for the region.

The country extended an open invite for cooperation from the international community, including those in the scientific and environmental sphere, in establishing and managing the multi-purpose MPA. The plan currently is to designate the vast majority ‚Äì 520,000 km¬≤ ‚Äì of the 650,000 km¬≤ area as a ‚Äòsustainable use zone‚Äô with ‚Äúlimited fishing activities‚Äù.

Additionally, there will be a conservation zone and habitat protection zone where Mauritius permits some controlled human activities. These will be accompanied by a strict conservation zone of around 37,000 km¬≤ that will have ‚Äústrictly controlled and limited‚Äù activity. Last, but by no means least, there will be a resettlement zone measuring some 9,000 km¬≤.

The Canary asked the Mauritian government whether it will permit industrial fishing, which is typically highly damaging to marine ecosystems, anywhere in the MPA. No comment was received by the time of publication.

Not an invitation for excessive exploitation

Pre-recorded comments at the event from Mauritius‚Äôs prime minister Pravind Jugnauth indicated that resettled Chagossians will be the ‚Äúfuture custodians of the MPA‚Äù. President of the Chagos Refugee Group Oliver Bancoult also spoke in the session. He left his island home of Peros Banhos in the archipelago at the age of four.

Bancoult asserted that assessments a few years after the Chagossians‚Äô removal showed that their around 200 year presence on the islands had left coral reefs in a ‚Äúnear pristine state‚Äù. Looking forward, he said:

we will run a sustainable and well-managed fisheries both to feed ourselves and to provide income and employment and, if possible, export food to other nations.

Bancoult further insisted that the MPA is ‚Äúnot an invitation to foreign states to remove precious resources from our homeland‚Äù.

Conservation is vital

As Rev Ocean‚Äôs Dr Alex Rogers explained in a pre-recorded presentation, the waters around the archipelago are extremely important in ecological terms. They contain between 25-50% of Indian ocean coral reefs considered in an excellent condition. Meanwhile, the fish in these reefs are six times as abundant as reefs elsewhere in the Indian ocean, which Rogers‚Äô presentation indicated was largely due to the presence of large fish, such as sharks.

Additionally, the locality is a key nesting area for both green and hawksbill turtles. It‚Äôs also important for bird species, with 12 of the islands ‚Äúclassifiable‚Äù as Important Bird Areas (IBAs) by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

Rogers explained that the proposed MPA contains both opportunities and risks. Done well, it could ensure protection of the reefs and wildlife, with Chagossians able to monitor and limit damaging activities, such as illegal fishing, after resettlement. But ensuring the sustainability of fishing activities ‚Äì particularly the protection of bigger fish such as sharks ‚Äì is paramount to its success.

Insufficient protections

According to speakers at the event, illegal fishing is an existing issue in the locality. Philippe Sands QC, legal advisor to the Mauritius government on the Chagos Islands, explained that the UK‚Äôs MPA is meant to be a ‚Äòno-take‚Äô zone aside from three nautical miles around the US base. But despite this, the UK hasn‚Äôt passed any regulations to enforce that zone. Moreover, he said that the UK only has a single vessel patrolling the 640,000 km¬≤ area.

The Canary asked the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office about the level of protection in its declared MPA and Mauritius‚Äôs plan. A spokesperson said:

We do not recognise the proposals made by Mauritius at the 2022 UN Oceans Conference. The UK declared the British Indian Ocean Territory Marine Protected Area in 2010.

Demands answered

Others in the UK, however, have taken a different position. Former Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn is honorary president of the Chagos Islands APPG. He told The Canary:

I welcome this Mauritian initiative because, unlike the BIOT MPA of April 2010, it is in conformity with international law and the requirements of international courts (ICJ, UNCLOS Tribunal) and the UN General Assembly.

He said that the UK‚Äôs MPA ‚Äúwas intended to be‚Äù a barrier to the resettlement that Mauritius‚Äôs plan offers the Chagossians. And he insisted that the APPG will continue to champion the cause of the Chagos community, some of whom live in the UK.

Corbyn highlighted that the Chagos community ‚Äúhave been extremely active in making their needs known over the years‚Äù. For some Chagossians, Mauritius‚Äôs plan for the MPA promises to meet those needs.

title: La ONU busca un nuevo tratado de protecci√≥n del oc√©ano en alta mar
text:
Seg√∫n la ONU, 3.000 millones de personas dependen del oc√©ano para la obtenci√≥n de alimentos, trabajo y recursos. Foto: Pixabay

La protecci√≥n de alta mar se discutir√° desde este lunes en Naciones Unidas con el objetivo de lograr un Tratado global e incluya todas las actividades que se desarrollan en el oc√©ano y actualice la Convenci√≥n sobre el Derechos del Mar (Convemar) de 1994, explica la representante de la organizaci√≥n High Seas Alliance, Gladys Mart√≠nez.

El oc√©ano es ¬´patrimonio de la humanidad¬ª, supone el 71 % de la superficie del planeta, con alta mar (m√°s conocida como √°rea m√°s all√° de la jurisdicci√≥n nacional o ABNJ, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) que abarca el 64 % y del que ¬´apenas est√° protegido el 1 %¬ª, se√±ala en entrevista con EFE Gladys Mart√≠nez, abogada costarricense que estar√° presente en la negociaciones para lograr un Tratado de Alta Mar, que se llevar√°n a cabo en Nueva York del 7 al 18 de marzo. (Le puede interesar: ¬øRastros de p√°ramos en la Amazonia de hace 15 millones de a√±os?)

Tratado de Alta Mar ¬´global e inclusivo¬ª

Las negociaciones -que llevan 15 a√±os- pretenden dar paso a ¬´un Tratado de Alta Mar global para la conservaci√≥n y uso sostenible de los recursos de las √°reas fuera de la jurisdicci√≥n de cada pa√≠s, y a la vez inclusivo, es decir que contemple todas las actividades que se desarrollen en ese espacio¬ª, actualizando as√≠ la Convemar.

La Convenci√≥n de Naciones Unidas sobre el Derecho al Mar (Convemar o tambi√©n conocida como CDM, CNUDM o UNCLOS, en ingl√©s) se firm√≥ en 1982 en Nueva York, sin embargo, solo entr√≥ en vigor en 1994, un a√±o despu√©s de la 60 ratificaci√≥n del documento por parte de Guyana.

El nuevo documento pretende regular actividades como la miner√≠a marina, porque ¬´existen muchos intereses y presiones¬ª actualmente en las negociaciones en la Autoridad Internacional de los Fondos Marinos (ISA, en ingl√©s) para otorgar permisos de explotaci√≥n a corto plazo, no solo de exploraci√≥n, cuando a√∫n no hay est√°ndares de impacto ambiental de una actividad que supondr√≠a un ¬´da√±o muy preocupante¬ª para los ecosistemas marinos ¬´que apenas se conocen¬ª, adem√°s del transporte de mercanc√≠as o la contaminaci√≥n.

Hay pa√≠ses que pretenden adem√°s que ¬´la pesca quede fuera de esta regulaci√≥n¬ª, seg√∫n Mart√≠nez, algo que ¬´permitir√≠a dejar la puerta abierta para excluir otras actividades como la miner√≠a marina, el transporte mar√≠timo, el cableado submarino¬ª. (Le sugerimos: As√≠ hemos afectado la migraci√≥n de las ballenas)

Marco regulatorio y sistema de gobernanza

Por ello, el nuevo Tratado busca crear ¬´un marco regulatorio y un sistema de gobernanza¬ª que adem√°s de englobar las actividades que se puedan desarrollar en alta mar¬ª, ¬´sea un documento robusto de implementaci√≥n, que contemple la obligaci√≥n de realizar ¬´estudios de impacto ambiental¬ª con unos ¬´est√°ndares altos¬ª que incluyan toda la cadena de impactos de una actividad y no solo en el lugar donde se realice, es decir que mida los efectos acumulativos de toda actividad¬ª.

Seg√∫n la representante de High Seas Alliance, organizaci√≥n que aglutina a 40 ongs y de la que forma parte la Uni√≥n Internacional para la Conservaci√≥n de la Naturaleza (UICN) para asesorar a las partes, esta reuni√≥n en la que est√°n presentes todos los pa√≠ses integrantes de la ONU ¬´deber√≠a ser la √∫ltima¬ª, no obstante, los efectos de la pandemia del covid-19 podr√≠a prolongar las negociaciones ¬´a una pr√≥xima cita¬ª hasta llegar a una resoluci√≥n de Naciones Unidas.

Las negociaciones se est√°n llevando a cabo por grupos regionales, explica Gladys Mart√≠nez -asesora del grupo de pa√≠ses de Latinoam√©rica-, ¬´entre los que Costa Rica y Chile han sido los m√°s activos para lograr un acuerdo¬ª, pero tambi√©n se encuentran dise√±ando sus estrategias el de la Uni√≥n Europea, el Caribe, los asi√°ticos, entre otros.

Adem√°s, aunque no es un grupo, intervienen los pa√≠ses que no tienen salida al mar liderados por Suiza, y en el que est√° -entre otros- Paraguay, porque no quieren quedar ¬´excluidos¬ª de los beneficios que se puedan obtener de los hallazgos en alta mar, como puedan ser ¬´la cura al c√°ncer o el elixir de la eterna juventud¬ª.

Todos los grupos regionales ¬´est√°n planteando en este momento¬ª sus posiciones y los puntos que van a debatir o acordar en la negociaci√≥n de los elementos de este Tratado en alta mar, espacio ¬´que incluye el cuerpo de agua¬ª, donde ¬´hay mucha vida y suceden muchos movimientos migratorios de especies¬ª.

Estructura y herramientas del Tratado

De ah√≠ la importancia del Tratado, que est√° compuesto por lo que los expertos conocen como ¬´elementos del paquete¬ª del documento e incluye -entre otros- ¬´las herramientas de manejo espacial marino, que abarcan las √°reas marinas protegidas y las reservas; las evaluaciones de impacto ambiental; los recursos gen√©ticos marinos y la creaci√≥n de capacidades y tecnolog√≠a¬ª.

Adem√°s de estos temas, subraya la abogada costarricense, en la negociaci√≥n del Tratado de Alta Mar se incluye aspectos que ¬´regulen la estructura¬ª del mismo, como la creaci√≥n de ¬´un comit√© cient√≠fico¬ª que revise continuamente lo que sucede en el oc√©ano y su evoluci√≥n, ¬´la celebraci√≥n de una conferencia de las partes (COP), entre otros aspectos¬ª. (Lea tambi√©n: M√°s de 3.000 millones de personas viven en contextos altamente vulnerables al cambio clim√°tico)

Asimismo, los grupos regionales estudian actualmente ¬´un texto enviado por la presidencia¬ª de la Convenci√≥n para la protecci√≥n del oc√©ano, un espacio que ocupa dos tercios del planeta, dice Mart√≠nez, y cuya importancia radica en que es uno de los reguladores del clima y de su conservaci√≥n y protecci√≥n depende que la crisis clim√°tica se reduzca al ser uno de los captores de las emisiones de di√≥xido de carbono (CO2) m√°s importantes.

title: Colombia's Operation Artemisa extends frontline to ocean protection | The City Paper Bogot√°
text:
Operation Artemisa was created in 2019 as a joint task force between the Ministries of Environment and Defense to combat illegal deforestation inside Colombia‚Äôs National Parks. Named after a Greek Goddess who with bow and arrow was the guardian of wildlife and protector of forests, ‚ÄúArtemisa‚Äù set out to secure large swathes of the Orinoco and Amazon basins in the interests of national security.

With plenty of military hardware to patrol remote regions of the country, Artemisa became a pillar of the government‚Äôs 2019/2020 National Development Plan, and for the former Presidential Security Advisor Rafael Guar√≠n, its core mission is to ‚Äúguarantee the nation‚Äôs integrity by protecting the essential right to water, a clean environment and biodiversity.‚Äù

In the on-going fight to protect endangered habits, Colombia‚Äôs eco-warriors are taking the frontline to the nation‚Äôs oceans, enlisting support from the Navy to target illegal fishing and indiscriminate trawling. During a visit to Gorgona National Park on Sunday, President Iv√°n Duque extended Artemisa‚Äôs reach to also focus on protecting coral reefs and atolls, home to 45% of world‚Äôs marine species. President Duque reiterated that the Navy maintains a permanent presence on Gorgona Island together with the National Coastguard.

Rear Admiral Francisco Hernando Cubides, Commander of the Pacific Naval Force, declared that the entire capacity of the Navy is available to meet the challenges of Artemisa at sea. ‚ÄúOur units in this region provide not only security, but environmental development in this important region of the country,‚Äù he stressed. Rear Admiral Cubides highlighted that Operation Artemisa includes Utr√≠a National Natural Park, Uramba Natural Park (Bah√≠a M√°laga, Valle del Cauca), Gorgona National Park, Malpelo Flora and Fauna Sanctuary, the Yurupar√≠ district, as well as the Sanquianga Park in Nari√±o.

Since launching in 2019, Artemisa‚Äôs 22,000-strong jungle guardians have managed to recover more than 146,000 hectares of tropical forest belonging to PNN Chiribiquete and the Llanos de Yar√≠ watershed. Hundreds of military sorties, have resulted in arrests of persons charged with environmental crimes, including setting fires in protected parkland, toxic chemical dumping, illegal mining and animal trafficking.

‚ÄúFor the first time in our history, we have aligned our domestic agenda, with foreign policy, and national security objectives with the sole aim of protecting our natural resources,‚Äù believes Guar√≠n. President Duque during the Glasgow COP26 Summit declared 30% of the nation‚Äôs total land and sea territory as ‚Äúprotected areas.‚Äù

text:
San Jos√©, 28 jun (EP/PL).- Costa Rica particip√≥ en Lisboa, Portugal, en la primera reuni√≥n de los pa√≠ses signatarios de la Declaraci√≥n para la Coalici√≥n Am√©rica por la protecci√≥n del Oc√©ano, inform√≥ hoy el Ministerio de Ambiente y Energ√≠a (Minae).

En esa primera cita, liderada por Chile y Canad√°, los participantes acordaron avanzar en la adopci√≥n de un plan de trabajo que aborde las oportunidades para mejorar la efectividad en la gobernanza de las √Åreas Marinas Protegidas ya establecidas y su interconexi√≥n biol√≥gica.

Efectuada durante la celebraci√≥n de la Conferencia de los Oc√©anos, presidida por Portugal y Kenya y que acoge Lisboa desde este lunes y hasta el viernes, en la reuni√≥n Costa Rica est√° representada por el titular del Minae, Franz Tattenbach y el canciller Arnoldo Andr√©.

title: Cuba ratifie ses engagements envers la protection des oc√©ans
text:
Photo: Prensa Latina

La Havane, 30 juin (RHC) Cuba a soulign√© ce jeudi √† Lisbonne que la gestion partag√©e des oc√©ans, ainsi que la r√©flexion sur leur durabilit√© doit √™tre l‚Äôune des priorit√©s de la gestion des gouvernements.

Lors de son discours √† la Conf√©rence sur les Oc√©ans, promue par les Nations Unies √† l‚Äôaide du Kenya et du Portugal, le premier vice-ministre cubain des Sciences, de la Technologie et de l‚ÄôEnvironnement, (CITMA), Jos√© Fidel Santana, a soulign√© l‚Äôimportance de ces affaires pour la survie et le d√©veloppement des petits √âtats insulaires.

Se r√©f√©rant √† la convention des Nations Unies sur le droit √† la mer, il a soulign√© que la rencontre de Lisbonne, ¬´ nous unit dans un objectif commun : Prot√©ger et pr√©server nos mers et nos oc√©ans ¬ª.

Jos√© Santana a d√©clar√© que cuba ratifie le fait que la protection de l‚Äôenvironnement au niveau mondial, doit √™tre conforme au principe de responsabilit√©s communes mais diff√©renci√©es, ainsi que sur l‚Äôimp√©ratif de coop√©ration r√©gionale et internationale, notamment dans les pays des Cara√Øbes, qui sont vuln√©rables et d√©pendent des secteurs tels que le tourisme.

Le premier vice-ministre du CITMA a signal√© que la plus grande √Æle des Antilles favorise la mise en ≈ìuvre de mod√®les de d√©veloppement durable, bas√©s sur les connaissances scientifiques et la technologie, l‚Äô√©thique, la politique environnementale orient√©e vers le d√©veloppement durable et refl√©tant les circonstances nationales.

En outre, le renforcement des m√©canismes pour la mise en ≈ìuvre, tels que les ressources financi√®res provenant de sources multilat√©rales, le renforcement des capacit√©s et le transfert de technologies, entre autres.

‚ÄúNous d√©fendons la promotion des oc√©ans comme source d‚Äô√©nergie propre et durable, ainsi que le besoin de financement pour le d√©veloppement d‚Äôune √©conomie circulaire favorisant la gestion des droits ¬ª, a-t-il ajout√©.

Pour Cuba, les questions li√©es √† l‚Äôenvironnement constituent une priorit√© strat√©gique, ce qui se refl√™te dans la nouvelle Constitution de la R√©publique, approuv√©e en 2019, o√π ¬´ vivre dans un environnement sain et √©quilibr√© ¬ª, est reconnu comme un droit citoyen, a-t-il soulign√©.

D‚Äôautre part, Santana a √©voqu√© une nouvelle loi sur le syst√®me de ressources naturelles et de l‚Äôenvironnement, r√©cemment approuv√©e, qui ¬´ consacre une partie de ses articles √† la protection sp√©ciale de nos eaux int√©rieures et les mers qui nous entourent ¬ª.

Il a expliqu√© que dans le Plan nationale de d√©veloppement √©conomique et social jusqu‚Äôen 2030, Cuba a propos√© des objectifs ambitieux pour l‚Äôeau, la r√©duction du plastique ; la pr√©vention et la confrontation des crimes et ill√©galit√©s qui affectent la flore et la faune sauvages.

En outre, nous avons √† pr√©sent 24 % de la production d‚Äô√©nergies √† partir de sources renouvelables et le recours aux transports terrestres √† faible taux d‚Äô√©mission s‚Äôest accru.

En 2017 notre pays a approuv√© le Plan de l‚Äô√âtat pour la lutte contre le changement climatique, a-t-il rappel√©.

Il a √©galement √©voqu√© le projet de r√©silience c√¥ti√®re au changement climatique √† Cuba, approuv√© par le Conseil d‚Äôadministration du Fonds vert pour le climat, malgr√© l‚Äôopposition solitaire des √âtats-Unis,¬ª comme une d√©monstration de la cruaut√© du blocus qui dure depuis plus de 60 ans pour de simples raisons politiques ¬ª.

Il a d√©plor√© la persistance de visions √©go√Østes et inamicales, de mesures unilat√©rales et des blocus √©conomique, qui ne rendent pas service √† la promotion des mers et d‚Äôoc√©ans plus propres, ainsi qu‚Äô√† la transition vers des √©conomies plus durables en fonction des vuln√©rabilit√©s et sur un pied d‚Äô√©galit√©.

title: Ecuador expands marine protected area around Gal√°pagos
text:
47043228-e2b6-4eab-a0dd-1a0e081597e2

Ecuador has created a huge new marine reserve north of the Gal√°pagos Islands, with the ultimate aim of forming a protected corridor north to Costa Rica.

The designation will help to protect a wide range of migratory oceanic fauna, including sharks, sea turtles and various bird species.



Sharks, such as Scalloped Hammerhead, are among the species that will benefit from the extension of the Marine Protected Area around the Gal√°pagos (Ryan Espanto / commons.wikimedia.org).

Ecuadorian president, Guillermo Laso, signed the decree creating the new reserve (called 'Hermandad', meaning brotherhood) and cut a ribbon made of materials collected from coastal clean-up operations conducted in the Gal√°pagos.

The new reserve is incorporated into an existing reserve that has existed since March 1998, expanding the marina protected area around the archipelago from 138,000 km2 to 198,000 km2.

Authorities are planning for protected areas in adjacent Colombia and Panama to join later, creating an international marine biosphere reserve that stretches north to Costa Rica's Cocos Island National Park, which was also recently expanded.

The creation of the Hermandad reserve is a "clear message for the world", said Lasso, who also described it as a "new relationship with the Earth, a new understanding of what constitutes progress for humanity".



Ecuadorian President Guillermo Lasso with the decree for the expansion of the Galapagos marine reserve.

Colombian President Ivan Duque and former US president Bill Clinton also attended the event, together with government officials from Costa Rica and Panama.

Duque said that eventually adding Colombia's Malpelo islands and Panama's Coiba islands to the vast marine reserve will allow for the safe migrations of fauna such as sea turtles, whales, sharks and manta rays.

The new reserve "will guarantee the survival of 40% of the world's marine species", Duque said.

Lasso added that "the seas are great regulators of the global climate" and that "taking care of them is not naive idealism, it is a vital necessity".

Located in the Pacific some 1,000 km (600 miles) off the coast of Ecuador, the Gal√°pagos is famous for its unique flora and fauna, made famous by British geologist and naturalist Charles Darwin's observations on evolution there.

title: Ecuador Expands Galapagos Islands Marine Protected Area
text:
By Alexandra Valencia (Reuters) Ecuador on Friday created a new marine reserve around its pristine Galapagos Islands ‚Äî whose rich biodiversity inspired Charles Darwin‚Äôs Theory of Evolution ‚Äî as it seeks to expand protections for endangered migratory species.

Extending the reserve by 60,000 square kilometers (23,166 square miles) is the first step in a plan agreed by Ecuador with its close neighbors Colombia, Costa Rica and Panama at the U.N. Climate Summit in Glasgow last year to create a common corridor through which species threatened by climate change and industrial fishing can migrate.

Also Read: Ecuador To Create New Galapagos Marine Reserve

The existing Galapagos marine reserve, one of the largest in the world, measures some 138,000 square kilometers (53,282 square miles), and the new conservation area will see 198,000 square kilometers (76,448 square miles) protected.

‚ÄúToday we‚Äôre declaring a marine reserve with an area of 60,000 square kilometers, equivalent to an area three times the size of Belize,‚Äù Ecuadorian President Guillermo Lasso said after signing the new reserve into existence aboard the Sierra Negra research vessel docked in Puerto Ayora on Santa Cruz Island, the Galapagos‚Äô tourist hub.

During the U.N. Climate Summit Lasso said he hoped the plan to expand the reserve would get financing via a conservation debt swap. However on Friday, Lasso did not reveal any financing details.

Environmentalists say the reserve will help protect at least five critically endangered species ‚Äî including hammer sharks, whale sharks, turtles, as well as other species that migrate between the Galapagos and Costa Rica‚Äôs Cocos Island.

Even though it will squeeze the space available to Ecuadorian fishing crews, it will not avoid the presence of a 300-ship Chinese fishing fleet https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecuador-environment-china/chinese-fishing-vessels-leave-area-near-ecuadors-galapagos-idUSKCN26D2VK?enowpopup that anchors in international waters just off the islands each year as they hunt for giant squid.

The impact of this fleet on the Galapagos‚Äô ecosystem has not yet been determined by Ecuador.

(Reporting by Alexandra Valencia Writing by Oliver Griffin; Editing by Sandra Maler, Reuters)

title: Ecuador Expands Galapagos Marine Protected Area by Nearly 50 Percent
text:
Ecuador Expands Galapagos Marine Protected Area by Nearly 50 Percent

President Guillermo Lasso displays the signed decree, Jan. 14 (Presidencia ECU)

On Friday, Ecuadoran President Guillermo Lasso formalized a new marine reserve, dramatically expanding the protected waters around the Galapagos Islands.

The decision was first announced in November, coinciding with the COP26 climate conference, and was finalized with a signing ceremony on Friday. The presidential decree establishes a new 17,500 square nautical mile marine protected area to the north of the Galapagos, called the Hermandad Marine Reserve. It expands the 39,000 square nm Galapagos Marine Reserve by nearly 50 percent.

The new reserve area is part of a planned marine thoroughfare for migratory sharks, whales, sea turtles, manta rays and other creatures that transit between the Galapagos and Costa Rica's Cocos Island, located about 400 nm to the northeast. Neighboring Colombia, Panama and Costa Rica are discussing plans to contribute marine reserves of their own to complete a continuous, protected path between and around the islands.

Half of the new Hermandad Reserve is fully protected from fishing activity, and the other half is covered by a longline fishing ban. The measure had strong local support in the tourism- and fishery-dependent Galapagos, according to the Pew Charitable Trusts.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre proud that our local community and the fishing industry came together in support of these marine protections. We all depend on the continued vitality of these rich waters and understand that preserving our ocean provides significant social, economic, and environmental benefits," said Ecuador's minister for the environment, Gustavo Manrique.

However, the expansion of the marine reserve will only change facts on the ground if it is enforced, according to conservationists. Enric Sala, head of the marine-reserve NGO Pristine Seas and a National Geographic explorer-in-residence, told the Washington Post that it's common to find longliners operating illegally inside of the existing Galapagos reserve. Without added enforcement effort, the same illegal fishing operations might continue in the new Hermandad Reserve, he suggested.

In remarks accompanying the signing of the decree, President Lasso called for a whole-of-society effort to preserve Ecuador's oceans. "I invite civil society, academia, private companies and NGOs to join this purpose. Let us continue joining efforts to conserve and care for this treasure of the Earth, for present and future generations," he said.

title: Clean Oceans Initiative expands target to ‚Ç¨4B for ocean protection
text:
France ‚Äì The Clean Oceans Initiative has doubled its commitment to protect the oceans by providing ‚Ç¨4 billion by 2025.

Together with Cassa Depositi e Prestiti (CDP), the Italian National Promotional Institution and Financial Institution for Development Cooperation, and ICO, the Spanish Promotional Bank, the Agence Fran√ßaise de D√©veloppement (AFD), the European Investment Bank (EIB), and KfW acting on behalf of the German Federal Government committed to double the Clean Oceans Initiative target. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) was also welcomed as a new member.

Given the threats to the oceans and the urgency to protect this natural resource, the Clean Oceans Initiative has decided to increase its funding target to ‚Ç¨4 billion by the end of 2025, rather than the ‚Ç¨2 billion originally planned for 2023.

Reducing plastic

The Clean Oceans Initiative is the world‚Äôs largest collaborative effort to fund projects aimed at reducing marine plastic pollution. In just three years, the Initiative has already met 80% of its goal by providing ‚Ç¨ 1.6 billion in long-term funding to public and private sector projects that improve solid waste, wastewater, and storm water management to reduce the discharge of plastics, microplastics, and other litter into the oceans. More than 20 million people in Africa, Asia, Latin America, and Europe will benefit from projects signed so far under the initiative.

Every year, more than 8 million tonnes of plastic waste is estimated to enter the oceans. Estuaries, coral reefs, fish, and millions of people who rely on the oceans are all threatened by pollution. The majority of plastic in the oceans comes from waste that has been thrown on the ground or washed into rivers. Many developing countries could reduce the 1.5 million tonnes of microplastics that end up in the oceans each year with better wastewater treatment and stormwater management. Plastic pollution is increasing in many cities around the world due to rapid population growth.

Food, medicines, renewable energy, and natural resources are just a few of the many benefits that the oceans provide to the planet and its inhabitants. The oceans provide a source of income and a healthy diet for billions of people. Oceans play an important role in climate change. They absorb about 30% of the world‚Äôs carbon dioxide, helping to mitigate the effects of global warming.

title: Capo Rizzuto Marine Protected Area: the place in Calabria where sea and history meet | Visititaly.eu
text: Established on December 27, 1991, it‚Äôs the largest in Italy in terms of side, covering an area of 14,721 hectares, 42.15 km of coastline and involving the municipality of Crotone and Isola Capo Rizzuto. The Protected Marine Area ‚ÄúCapo Rizzuto‚Äù offers to visitors an exclusive itinerary through an heritage of considerable value, in which nature converges with history and archeology: a journey between the legend and the myth, with scent of a crystalline sea that bathes the fine amber sand and the steep cliffs. With its eight promontories, the area includes two places of interest with very ancient origins: it‚Äôs bordered to the north by the Lacinio promontory, on which stands the archeological site of Capo Colonna and in which you can find, along with many remains of buildings, the last surviving column of the temple dedicated to Hera (or Era), the Greek patron deity of marriage; in the meantime it‚Äôs bordered to the south by Punta delle Castella or more commonly le Castella, a fishing village and fraction of Isola Capo Rizzuto, rich of Greek-Roman archaeological remains and are still visible, as well as by the famous Aragonese Castle, a probable Magna Graecia fortification erected on a small peninsula on the sea. The establishment of the Protected Marine Area derives from a dual objective: environmental preservation, unique for the entire costal area, and archaeological preservation, given the rich heritage that holds it. Stretches of rocky coasts alternate with expanses of very fine sands, wet by a sea rich of flora and fauna that has the peculiar characteristic of being very low compared to all the other depths of the Calabria coast.

title: The French Southern Territories National Nature Reserve becomes the second largest marine protected area in the world - OCTA
text:
On the occasion of the One Ocean Summit, held in Brest (France) from February 9 to 11, the President of the French Republic, Emmanuel Macron, announced the extension of the French Southern Territories National Nature Reserve to cover all the maritime areas of the Crozet and Kerguelen archipelagos and the islands of Saint-Paul and Amsterdam.

With 1.6 million km2, this reserve located in the south of the Indian Ocean becomes the largest marine protected area in France, and the second largest in the world.

This extension of nearly one million km2 is one of the key measures of the French National Strategy for Protected Areas 2030, and allows France to exceed the target of 30% of French maritime and terrestrial areas in protected areas.

This measure also highlight the richness of the exceptional natural heritage of the French Southern Territories, which harbor a rich biodiversity, representative of the biological diversity of the Southern Ocean. For example, there is the world‚Äôs largest population of king penguins, and the second largest population of elephant seals. The French Southern Territories also represent the migration route of Antarctic blue and pygmy whales, as well as the reserve of a great diversity of endemic or sub-endemic birds. Finally, these areas also act as carbon sinks, thus contributing to the climate balance.

title: ‚ÄòLau seascape will be a marine protected area‚Äô
text:
Fiji is pursuing the biggest ocean governance transformation in its history, says Prime Minister Voreqe Bainimarama. Addressing the Oceans Conference in Portugal, he said this was perhaps one of the biggest in the world.

‚ÄúNot because it‚Äôs simple or comfortable, but because these protections can‚Äôt wait,‚Äù Mr Bainimarama said.

‚ÄúThese investments can‚Äôt wait, nor can the jobs they create.

‚ÄúIn two years‚Äô time, the Lau seascape, an area representing 8 per cent of Fiji‚Äôs ocean, will be a marine protected area, our largest step to date towards protecting 30 per cent of our ocean by 2030.‚Äù

Mr Bainimarama said by 2030, Fiji would achieve total real-time surveillance of its waters.

‚ÄúWe will be virtually single-use plastic free and recycle all PET bottles; ocean literacy will be mandatory within our education system and we‚Äôll lower carbon emissions in our shipping sector by 40 per cent.

‚ÄúBy 2030, we will produce at least 160k metric tonnes of sustainably farmed and harvested ocean product, supporting 53,000 new jobs on the way to supply half of our blue foods from sustainable fisheries by 2035. ‚ÄúAnd by 2050 we aim to create 100,000 new jobs in sustainable fisheries.‚Äù

He also said by 2050, Fiji would be a net-zero society.

‚ÄúOur fisherfolk will have universal access to electric outboard motors, the Pacific will be home to a green shipping fleet and all fishing nets in Fijian waters will be biodegradable.‚Äù

title: Our Ocean Conference in Palau to highlight role of Pacific in ocean protection
text:
Palau President Surangel Whipps Jr said that Our Ocean Conference next month will be an opportunity for the Pacific region to highlight the role of Pacific Islanders as stewards of the oceans.

In a virtual Our Ocean Conference pre-event sponsored by the Sasakawa Foundation, President Whipps said Pacific nations have always taken ‚Äúgreat responsibility‚Äù in the management and protection of the ocean.

He said ground breaking ocean initiative originated by the Pacific including the famed Palau National Marine Sanctuary (PNMS).

But at the same time, the region is facing threats from the impact of climate change.

‚ÄúThe Pacific islands have been at the forefront of the climate, the climate change impacts. We have been hit by storms, sea-level rise, droughts, you name it, we have it. And now all of those lead to huge economic losses. In fact, it even affects our tourism industry because it destroys our coral reefs. kills our jellyfish and we‚Äôre concerned about the impacts that will have to the tuna of stocks,‚Äù President Whipps said.

Palau is hosting the conference in Palau on 13- 14 April, marking the first time that the Our Ocean Conference will be hosted by a small island developing state.

The conference is expected to spur global ocean action and commitments to advance sustainable fishing, promote marine protected areas, combat ocean plastic pollution, support maritime security, foster a blue economy, and create an ocean resilient to climate impacts.

Minister of Agriculture Fisheries and Environment (MAFE) Steven Victor said the conference is the chance to ‚Äúcontinue to engage the global community in looking at ocean issues.‚Äù

He also called on the nations to prioritise actions on the ocean, especially during the post-Covid-economy.

‚ÄúSo we are at a crossroad here in Palau in really looking at recovery from the pandemic and reevaluating our ocean policies that ensure that we find the balance between large-scale ocean conservation and sustainable developments that support small island developing states,‚Äù he said.

title: Fiji is leading the fight in ocean protection: PM Gateway to Fiji, Fiji News, Fiji Rugby, Fiji Football, Fiji Sports, Fiji Picture Gallery, Fiji Business, etc
text:
Prime Minister Voreqe Bainimarama says that by 2030, 30 percent of Fiji‚Äôs ocean with Fiji‚Äôs Exclusive Economic Zone will be protected from exploitation, degradation and held in a Trust for generations to come.



He made this statement at the launch of the Marine Protected Area National Consultation at the i-Taukei Trust Board grounds, this morning.



Bainimarama said Fiji has put forward some of the most comprehensive ocean and climate commitments on the planet.



He said that Fiji has just launched 17 Voluntary Commitments towards the protections and sustainable management of Fiji‚Äôs oceans at the United Nations Oceans Conference which Fiji co-hosted with Sweden.

‚ÄúWe walked the talk by embedding the implementation, monitoring and evaluation process of our commitment into law.‚Äù



‚ÄúGovernment‚Äôs ocean commitments are enshrined in Fiji‚Äôs five-year and 20-year National Development Plan in 2017; and most recently factored into Fiji‚Äôs National Oceans Policy and historic Climate Change Act,‚Äù he added.



He said that in his meetings with the US President Joe Biden he conveyed in no uncertain terms the criticality of the moment.



‚ÄúThe Pacific Ocean cleans the air we breathe ‚Äì virtually operating as earth‚Äôs single lung now following the widespread destruction of the Amazon rainforest.‚Äù



‚ÄúSecondly, without a doubt, the Pacific will provide the protein needed for a much of the world in the future through fish and seafood.‚Äù



He said for this to continue it needs to be protected.



‚ÄúWe need to engineer a highly sustainable, conservation-learning and forward-looking blue and green economy ‚Äì from green shipping to aqua-culture, to carbon trading and to expanding our marine protected areas.‚Äù



He said the US was increasing its contribution to the green climate fund, which is beneficial to all Small Island States, including Fiji.



He added that the Pacific-European Union Marine Partnership Program is also helping Fiji address some of the most serious challenges faced in the Pacific including the increasing depletion of fisheries resources.

title: OECMs: HELCOM investigates alternative marine protection measures
text:
To investigate the potential of protective measures in the Baltic Sea beside marine protected areas (MPAs), HELCOM, in cooperation with the FAO and IUCN WCPA, held a workshop on other effective area-based conservation measures, or OECMs, on 1-3 February 2022.

‚ÄúOECMs, a relatively novel conservation approach, are an important part of the HELCOM agenda as well, as reflected by the 2021 Baltic Sea Action Plan, which contains no fewer than seven actions related to spatial conservation measures, and which explicitly refers to OECMs in several places,‚Äù said R√ºdiger Strempel, the Executive Secretary of HELCOM, adding that OECMs could, among other things, contribute to strengthening the overall coherence of the HELCOM MPA network.

The workshop contributed to developing a common understanding of the applicability of the OECM criteria to the specific situation in the Baltic Sea, as well as a better comprehension of the potential of OECMs for supporting the attainment of the HELCOM objectives on marine conservation, including their interplay with existing MPAs.

‚ÄúOECMs should have a spatial component, bring clear biodiversity benefits that are long lasting, and should not cause any significant harm to other biodiversity attributes as a consequence of their implementation,‚Äù explained Jannica Haldin, the Deputy Executive Secretary of HELCOM.

According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), the distinguishing criterion between MPAs and OECMs is that the former have a primary conservation objective, whereas OECMs deliver effective in-situ conservation of biodiversity regardless of their primary objectives.

‚ÄúFrom the perspective of biodiversity in the sea, labels do not matter ‚Äì what matters is the effect a measure has on the environment,‚Äù said Haldin. ‚ÄúThe main principle of OECMs is that they must provide a positive outcome for biodiversity.‚Äù

‚ÄúUsing a measure as a starting point is what differentiates the OECM process from traditional conservation approaches, and enables us to consider the effect of measures that weren‚Äôt initially put in place for conservation purposes,‚Äù added Haldin.

The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) defines other effective area-based conservation measures as areas other than protected areas including MPAs that ‚Äúachieve positive and sustained long-term outcomes for the in-situ conservation of biodiversity‚Äù, which in turn contributes to preserving ‚Äúecosystem functions and services‚Äù and in some cases ‚Äúcultural, spiritual, socio‚Äìeconomic, and other locally relevant values‚Äù.

The workshop was attended by a broad range of stakeholders dealing with issues related to the marine environment, bringing together representatives of government agencies, non-governmental organization and academia.

Catherine Chabaud est profond√©ment engag√©e dans la protection des oc√©ans. L'ancienne navigatrice est aujourd'hui d√©put√©e europ√©enne et croit √† l'action politique pour changer les choses.

Au niveau europ√©en, toute l'attention est port√©e aujourd'hui sur la mise en oeuvre du pacte vert, ce fameux "green deal" qui devrait permettre de faire entendre la voix de l'oc√©an. L'oc√©an, bien commun de l'humanit√©

Depuis son arriv√©e au parlement europ√©en, Catherine Chabaud et plusieurs scientifiques comme l'oc√©anographe Fran√ßoise Gaill, plaident pour que l'oc√©an soit class√© "bien commun de l'humanit√©". text:
Une fa√ßon de boucler la boucle. Quelques mois avant la fin de son quinquennat, le pr√©sident de la R√©publique, Emmanuel Macron, veut afficher son volontarisme sur le plan de la diplomatie environnementale. ‚Üí RELIRE. Climat : les oc√©ans, r√©gulateurs thermiques, se m√©langent moins

‚Üí TRIBUNE. ¬´ Comment les baleines et les oc√©ans peuvent nous aider √† lutter contre le r√©chauffement climatique ¬ª

En priorit√©, la n√©gociation d‚Äôun trait√© mondial pour prot√©ger la haute mer, dont le prochain tour de n√©gociations est pr√©vu √† l‚ÄôONU en mars. Les ONG craignent que les n√©gociations aboutissent √† un trait√© a minima, sans mesures concr√®tes qui permettraient une limitation de la surp√™che ou du transport maritime dans ces zones prot√©g√©es.

text:

text:

Les √©lus du Parti communiste et du PS se font plus timides.

Pourquoi est-il primordial que la France agisse pour la protection des oc√©ans ?

La France doit prot√©ger ces zones maritimes, sauvegarder leur biodiversit√©, pour le bien-√™tre de la plan√®te, du climat, des citoyens. √Ä l‚Äôheure actuelle, la politique d‚ÄôEmmanuel Macron est anti-environnementale. Il a d√©pass√© le stade de l‚Äôinaction, car dans les faits, il agit contre le climat. Ses actes et les politiques qu‚Äôil entreprend sont √† l‚Äôinverse de ce qu‚Äôil faut pour sauver la plan√®te et l‚Äôhumanit√©.

En 2021, Emmanuel Macron affirmait avoir pour objectif de prot√©ger 30 % des espaces maritimes et terrestres, dont 10 % plac√©s sous ¬´ protection forte ¬ª. Aujourd‚Äôhui, nous avons d√©pos√© un recours contre le d√©cret 2022-527 du 12 avril dernier, qui d√©finit la mise en ≈ìuvre de ces espaces particuliers, car dans ce texte, la d√©finition des aires marines sous ¬´ protection totale¬ª ou ¬´ forte¬ª ne respecte pas les standards internationaux. Au Royaume-Uni, ce sont 39 % de ces espaces maritimes qui sont plac√©s sous protection forte ou int√©grale. En France, on est √† moins de 4 % de zones marines r√©ellement prot√©g√©es. Nous sommes lamentablement en retard !

En voyant le d√©cret du gouvernement, on a compris qu‚ÄôEmmanuel Macron n‚Äôavait aucune volont√© d‚Äô√™tre honn√™te ou s√©rieux sur les sujets √©cologiques. Les promesses faites ont encore √©t√© instrumentalis√©es √† des fins √©lectorales. Ces mensonges constants sont destructeurs pour la d√©mocratie. text:
The oceans cover more than 70% of the surface of our planet.

France has adopted a series of measures to protect its sea fauna and flora. Businesses are innovating to reduce human impact on the ocean.

Small-scale fishers represent 50% of worldwide fishing in quantity every year. While industrial fishing boats are tracked and monitored, the two million small, under-12-meter boats that crisscross the world‚Äôs seas and oceans are not. To fill this gap, French company CLS ‚Äì which is based in Nantes ‚Äì developed the Nemo transceiver. Targeted specifically at the small-scale fishing sector, the transceiver uses mini-satellite data to monitor the activity of boats. Several countries, including the United Kingdom and Gabon, have adopted the system and require their fishers to purchase a Nemo transceiver to make sure they don‚Äôt stray into protected areas. The authorities can therefore model the health of the marine environment, take measures to prevent overfishing, and sustainably manage fish resources. The Nemo transceiver is self-powered by a solar panel, which facilitates its adoption in poorly developed areas with no electricity supply. It also has an emergency button that can be used to call for assistance in the event of a problem.

CLS is a perfect illustration of how La French Fab is innovating to develop ocean protection. Underwater ecosystems are not only endangered by overfishing, but also by pollution, oil & gas exploitation, and global warming which is causing ocean acidification. Last year, in response to these worrying trends, the United Nations Organization introduced a Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development (2021-2030). France aims to play a leading role in ocean conservation. In February it hosted the One Ocean Summit in Brittany, the first ever global summit on the issue. The stakes are high: oceans absorb 90% of the heat generated by greenhouse gases. Without their regulating effect, humanity would not survive.

France has a key role to play. With its 10.2 million square kilometers of marine area, it has the second biggest exclusive economic zone (EEZ) in the world. It has turned 30% of it into protected marine areas, the most well-known being the Coral Sea and the French Southern and Antarctic Lands. The government has also introduced fish conservation areas, anti-collision systems on French boats to protect cetaceans, as well as measures to protect mangroves and coral reefs in French overseas territories. The French Fab community is contributing to the national effort. French firms in the nautical, fishing, maritime transport, energy, cosmetics, and material production industries have adopted the Ocean Benchmark developed by the Sea Foundation. Thanks to this tool, which is based on UN Sustainable Development Goal 14 (Life Below Water), businesses can measure and improve the impact of their interactions with the ocean. A collective effort is required. La French Fab is firmly committed to doing its bit.

text:
Sur la base d‚Äôun document r√©dig√© par des d√©cideurs politiques gabonais, des ONG et des chercheurs de l‚ÄôUniversit√© d‚ÄôExeter, en Angleterre, mettant en √©vidence un plan pour la protection des oc√©ans et sa gestion du r√©seau d‚Äôaires marines prot√©g√©es (AMP), le Gabon est per√ßu comme un leader mondial en mati√®re de protection des oc√©ans.

Dans le cadre de l‚Äô√©valuation des progr√®s accomplis par les Etats au cours de la derni√®re d√©cennie dans la lutte contre les facteurs sous-jacents qui influencent les pressions directes sur la biodiversit√© et dans la formulation de nouvelles politiques et strat√©gies pour la d√©cennie √† venir, le Gabon √† travers la conservation marine, demeure l‚Äôun des rares pays √† avoir respect√© et d√©pass√© les engagements internationaux relatifs √† la couverture mondiale des aires marines prot√©g√©es (AMP) de 10 % fix√© en 2010.

En effet, depuis l‚Äôannonce d‚Äôun nouveau r√©seau d‚ÄôAMP en 2014, le Gabon a cr√©√© 20 aires prot√©g√©es, augmentant ainsi la protection de ses eaux de moins de 1 % √† 26 %. Un mod√®le salu√© par les chercheurs de l‚ÄôUniversit√© d‚ÄôExeter, qui estiment √† travers un document r√©dig√© en collaboration avec des d√©cideurs politiques gabonais et des ONG, que les ¬´ le√ßons de ce travail et sa pertinence ailleurs ¬ª, peuvent √™tre utilis√©es dans de nombreux autres pays pour √©clairer les engagements et la mise en ≈ìuvre de la biodiversit√© mondiale post-2020.

¬´Nous avons appris du processus qui a abouti √† la cr√©ation des parcs nationaux terrestres du Gabon par Omar Bongo en 2007 et avons √©t√© capable de fournir le cadre scientifique et juridique pour faire de la vision du pr√©sident Ali Bongo Ondimba, d‚Äôune √©conomie bleue durable, une r√©alit√© ¬ª, a d√©clar√© le ministre en charge de l‚ÄôEnvironnement, Lee White, relay√© par nos confr√®res du media en ligne euronews.com

Selon le Pr Brendan Godley, de l‚ÄôUniversit√© d‚ÄôExeter, ¬´ en √©tendant les mesures de conservation et de gestion des p√™ches √† l‚Äôensemble de sa ZEE, le Gabon a pris des mesures importantes pour assurer la persistance √† long terme de sa biodiversit√© marine et de ses ressources halieutiques, et devrait √™tre c√©l√©br√© comme un exemple mondial¬ª

Publi√©es dans la revue ¬´Conservation Letters¬ª et intitul√© : ¬´Fulfilling global marine engagements; les le√ßons apprises du Gabon ¬ª, ces r√©ussites du Gabon proposent une approche en quatre √©tapes pour les pays et les donateurs : premi√®rement, les √âtats doivent renforcer et maintenir leur capacit√© de recherche et de mise en ≈ìuvre, en veillant √† ce que les preuves scientifiques sous-tendent les d√©cisions politiques. Deuxi√®mement, les pays devraient s‚Äôengager publiquement √† adopter des objectifs mondiaux de conservation marine, signalant leur engagement envers la communaut√© internationale et les donateurs potentiels.

Troisi√®mement, la communaut√© de la conservation devrait r√©agir en aidant √† cr√©er ou √† renforcer les agences environnementales du pays, soit directement, soit, si les garanties financi√®res sont faibles, via des organisations internationales. Quatri√®mement, chaque agence de mise en ≈ìuvre devrait diriger l‚Äô√©laboration de cadres nationaux de conservation marine, en travaillant avec les parties prenantes et les donateurs pour produire des plans ambitieux mais politiquement r√©alisables, combinant autant que possible des initiatives descendantes avec des approches ascendantes.

Ces quatre √©tapes d√©pendent d‚Äôun financement √† long terme pour maintenir l‚Äô√©lan, la capacit√© et la sensibilisation, mais le Gabon montre que le financement √† court terme peut √©galement √™tre efficace, seulement s‚Äôil fait partie d‚Äôun programme plus large et coordonn√© bas√© sur des fondations solides. Cependant, le plus grand d√©fi auquel sont confront√©s de nombreux pays, y compris le Gabon, est d‚Äôobtenir des financements pour √©tablir et g√©rer des AMP, dont il a √©t√© d√©montr√© qu‚Äôils √©voluent avec la couverture et qu‚Äôils sont plus √©lev√©s pour les AMP √† usage multiple.

title: Marine Protection | MeerWissen German-African Initiative
text:
The first teams began their work in 2019, projects being funded with up to 250,000 euros. Eleven projects are currently in their final phase, and one has already been concluded. Four new projects are to be launched in the summer of 2022. 32 institutions in all are taking part in the initiative: in Germany, these include the GEOMAR Helmholtz Centre for Ocean Research, the Alfred Wegener Institute and Kiel University, while the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI), the University of Namibia and the Tanzania Fisheries Research Institute (TAFIRI) are among those participating in Africa. One of the central guiding principles of MeerWissen is to establish partnerships on an equal footing. As St√∂bener explains, African institutions were given access to the technologies, innovations and networks of German marine research. The latter profits in turn from the expertise of its African partners, which allows it to gear its work to national and regional agendas and requirements.

More knowledge about eels

The Bremerhaven-based Th√ºnen Institute for example is regarded as one of the world‚Äôs leading centres of research into freshwater eels. In the MeerWissen project BIOEELS-TZ, the researchers draw on their knowledge of eels in temperate zones to research tropical species. Tanzania is home to more than 40 eel-like fishes; some of these snake-like bony fishes are endangered. To protect them, the biodiversity of migrating eels in coastal rivers is being studied, among other things.

The university in Dar es Salaam and the TAFIRI are responsible for the socioeconomic part of the project, as BIOEELS-TZ combines biology and the social sciences. Part of the research involves interviewing fishermen, for instance. Because eels react sensitively to environmental changes and Tanzania‚Äôs population is set to see considerable growth, it is important to preserve the eels, protect their natural habitats and ensure sustainable fishing.

For diversity in the seas

Mouhamed Moustapha Fall and Kwabena Owusu from the African Institute for Mathematical Sciences (AIMS) in Senegal and Agostino Merico from the Leibniz Centre for Tropical Marine Research (ZMT) in Bremen are convinced that their project INDUCE can have a political impact. Though the coasts of Senegal are characterised by great biodiversity, these areas are also important for the country‚Äôs economy. ‚ÄúThe project INDUCE seeks to produce sound scientific knowledge for the conservation of fish functional diversity from socially inclusive and environmentally sustainable economic growth perspectives in Senegal‚Äù, says Owusu . The ZMT and the AIMS have already been working together for almost ten years, and the Oceanographic Research Center of Dakar-Thiaroye (CRODT) is now also involved in INDUCE. Together they are studying the diversity of fish species in Senegal.
